When I went to see it at the theater, everyone in the room was laughing, and for you ladies, you get to see Brad Pitt's chest, hot stuff,for you guys Jolie wears some pretty slinky stuff, but don't take my word for it, go see it yourself you won't be disappointed.

title: Great Movie - much better than expected
review:
Like many I was apprehensive about seeing this , figuring it was all about chemistry and wouldn't be that great on the actual story.

Boy was I wrong.

From the beginning of the two of them sitting in a doctor's office (as shown in the trailer), throughout the entire movie, I felt like I was watching a "married" Butch Cassidy and Sundance.

It may be a victim of poor marketing - is it an action movie, a comedy or a romance? It's all three. When we were walking in, I thought "PG?" come on - but seriously, there is nothing in this movie that anyone would not enjoy or be offended at. It's just plain FUNNY. And not funny bad but everyone was laughing in the theatre at the jokes and this has sequel needed, written all over it.

Certainly Brad Pitt looks like he's enjoying himself, much like in Ocean's 11 and 12 , as opposed to being a caricature (as in Troy) and Jolie never looked or acted better. I can certainly see why people who saw this while being made said these two should be together. I can't imagine anyone else being able to pull off the whole married assassin look.

Personally, I can't wait for the DVD and I would pay extra for the premium stuff with outtakes, etc. I'm almost ready to go see it again.

title: A little harmless, implausible fun
review:
"Hey Johnny! So how is Mr. and Mrs. Smith?" Well, what exactly are you expecting from the movie? "Hmm, I'd say the action of Revenge of the Sith combined with the the clever script of Memento. Oh, and with complete plausibility thrown in for good measure." Ah, well in that case I would have to say you should probably be flogged with a wet, jello-filled straw. Don't worry, it's not too bad. Trust me. Then you should take my course, "How to Properly Analyze a Movie Based on its Trailer." It'll help you look a lot less like a jack-a-dandy and prevent you from complaining about how this movie is just too unbelievable.

Too unbelievable? You don't say. Look, right off the bat we're expected to believe that this couple has been married for 5 or 6 years, they're trained assassins who pride themselves on recon, and they never suspected the other of being an assassin. If you can buy that premise going into the movie then you waiver all rights to complain about anything else that's a bit far-fetched, OK?

Is this a great movie that I'll gladly add to my DVD collection the day it's released? Nah. But it was good for a couple of hours of non-analytical fun. It's a little slow-paced at times, and there is probably too much emphasis at the beginning on the mundanity of their marriage (they're bored, we get it), but once things start to kick in we get beautiful people, gunplay, car chases, explosions, one-line exchanges, inside jokes, and doses of humor thrown at us left, right, and up the middle. I'd also add "out the ying-yang" but that'd be too cliché. The fight scene between Brad and Angelina is particularly funny (though probably a little too reflective of a day in the life of Ike Turner), as is Vince Vaughn's small role. You gotta love his defense of living with his mom, "She cooks, cleans, makes my bed, and I'm the dumb guy?"

If you're looking for character development then you better keep on looking. Chances are you won't ever buy into the fact that you're supposed to be watching the lives of Mr. and Mrs. Smith on screen. More likely you'll be thinking as I did, "Hey, there's Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie just having some fun!" But who cares? As long as it entertains then so be it. It doesn't really take itself seriously, so why should you?

I mean, come on, Angelina Jolie walks out of gunfights and explosions looking like she just walked out of a salon, so what are you expecting? It's funny because this prompted my sister Amber to comment, "I wish I could get blown up and still have my hair looking nice." To which I inquired, "Why would you want to get blown up in the first place? How about just wishing for your hair to look nice and not worry about being involved in an explosion?" Amber's response? "I'm just saying, if I were in a gunfight or explosion then I wish I'd walk away looking as fixed up as Angelina Jolie was." Oh. Well, THAT makes sense. *shakes head* Women.

THE GIST

There are some pretty cool scenes that I wouldn't mind witnessing again one day, but there are also some clunkers that I'd fast forward through just so I could get to the good stuff. In a Summer full of heavier (albeit entertaining) material, if all you want is to watch a bunch of beautiful people blow stuff up and aid you in a little escapism, then Mr. and Mrs. Smith just might satisfy.

3.5 marks (out of 5)

title: Downright Fun - a great night out! Will see this one again!
review: What an extremely pleasant surprise this was! I went to see this film mainly because, like most males in the 18-25 age bracket, I am quite partial to the wiles of Angelina Jolie. I had also seen the trailers a number of times and thought there was potential in it. However, I didn't have extremely high hopes because most of the stuff coughed up by Hollywood lately has been far from inspirational! The deciding factor to see it was a cousin on the opposite side of the spectrum who, as with most females in the afore mentioned 18-25 age bracket, is rather obsessed with Mr. Pitt. I hadn't been out in a while so why not, right!? The style of the film was perfect. How could it not be with such a director! The scenes wafted smoothly, gliding from scene to scene effortlessly. The pace gradually picked up until reaching its peak and the ending was actually quite ingenious - The final shootout was most enjoyable to watch as it didn't opt for the usual - and highly unoriginal - "Bang Bang, you're Dead"! The acting was something that I thought would be a concern. The film had seemed to me to be mainly a vehicle for adolescents to purve of the perfectly sculpted bodies of Jolie and Pitt. But they were actually really good. Brad Pitt is very adept at this style of comedy (as he displays in the "Ocean's" films) and Jolie is perfect in her role - it didn't require too much from her as she is a natural seductress but I didn't question her character once which means she did the job well! Another testament to their acting abilities is during the dinner scene after the big "revelation". With hardly any dialog they both manage to convey the tense situation to the audience who have no doubt in their minds about what is going on - not only was it a highly comedic scene, but it was pulled off so well that one can only take one's hat off to not only Pitt and Jolie, but also the director and writer alike! The music was downright funky, but without becoming overpowering. It was subtle yet poignant and therefore perfect. While the storyline itself was a tad weak and far-fetched, it doesn't really bother you as it is such an enjoyable film to watch that you just don't care. And at least it isn't inane. It is a very original film with quite a nice little message about marriage and "sticking together" and all that jazz. And that final scene is exactly what was needed. It brought the audience back to planet earth, settled them down and gave them one final laugh - leaving them with a very pleasant taste in their mouths and a desire for more. It achieved exactly what a film should achieve - a great deal of fun and a sense that the huge amount of money spent on the tickets was worth it for this one!

title: An Action Packed, Exaggerated, but Effective Metaphor for Marriage in the Modern (jungle) World
review: The basic plot is of two secret assassins working for opposite agencies but who happen to meet, fall in love, and marry without knowing that they are both assassins for opposing agencies. Assassins, since they have fake identities and jobs, are not supposed to reveal their actual occupations or for whom they work. Such an arrangement, of course, would not encourage much authentic sharing in a marriage. In the beginning, they have the romantic and erotic excitement of their relationship to share, but as all couples find out, the flame of eroticism eventually turns into dying embers and, typically, there is nothing to fan it back to life. Also, beginning couples are satisfying their curiosity about what each other are really like. This 'also' part, of necessity, has to be missing from this ill-fated pairing of the aptly named 'John' and 'Jane' 'Smith'; the secret assassins working for opposing agencies. This movie is in part an exaggerated metaphor for communication in modern marriages in which couples' lives outside of the home have little in common with each other. Like the modern marriage, when interdependence begins to become a tug of war for equality and equity in sharing responsibilities and negotiation falters, then sharing personal, intimate information merely makes each more vulnerable to blackmail, one-up-man-ship, or revenge as they alternate between roles of victim and victimizer. This movie, then, is also a metaphor for a tight-lipped standoff in marriage. After a few years of unsuccessfully trying to form and maintain sharing roles in the home, staleness permeates the marital air. What are more critical in this case are the long, dry, empty years of not being able to communicate and 'share' what their daily life is like. Hence, they surrender and begin to accept their boredom with one another. So they, as with many couples, do not give up without a last 'token' attempt to salvage the marriage by seeing a marriage counselor. The script for the counseling sessions is compressed into brief statements, by both clients and counselor, which epitomizes the very essence of a typically long, spitefully, and pitifully drawn out process that in the end trudges down an inevitable road to failure and divorce. After the glow, and the ashes of a burned out marriage are about to be thrown out, suddenly there is an 'assignment' in which John and Jane are, seemingly, accidentally pitted against one another. Here, the plot thickens as they each discover they had attempted to 'rub out' one another. Through an of un-covering of each other's true identity and attempt at mutual destruction, the years of smoldering disaffection and resentment explodes into a pressure-cooker of roiling rage. Back home, they each deftly play the domesticated cat while suspecting the other of a sneaky plot to pounce with the lethal blow on their wary mouse. They continue circling in a to-the-death bout but now, as more open assaults at one another unfold, their roles of predators and prey escalate. Egged on by their co-workers, all out battle rages but ends in a draw. In the course of the battle they begin to have a genuine respect for each other's equality in skill and courage. This is the first key turning point. In spite of the great show of determination to destroy, they do not, well, really, emotionally they cannot, bring it off. The secret of their hidden, deep, persistent-against-all-odds love for each ekes out when neither can strike the final blow. This is the second key turning point. Being off guard in the heat of their battles, they are confused when the stealth troupes of both of their agencies enter the fray, attacking both of them. After successfully fending off onslaughts from both sides they meet with John's fellow agent who informs them that they indeed are both targets because no one wants two secret assassins of opposing agencies to be marriage partners. However, they are told that they have a way out. They must find the person, now being held hostage, who was target of the assignment when the fiasco started and surrender him to the agencies. Again, unsuspectingly, they are being setup by both sides so both of these birds can be killed with one stone (Uzi). Nevertheless, they eventually 'get it' and seize this as an opportune moment because they see that by the two best of the best killers teaming up they may defeat the assassins' assassins. When they survive after a harrowing all out war waged by hordes of the agencies' hit men, they pull out all the stops in brutal interrogation and confessing the truth about themselves. Surviving the worst of odds together forms the bond they had longed for all along. They now begin a genuine attempt at an authentic relationship based on mutual respect and a win-win strategy for negotiating equality and equity. Once again, love triumphs against all odds. The final metaphor for modern marriage is that fighting it out as equals, neither one surrendering ground, and developing mutual respect as equals with mutual support in their struggle to survive in the modern world can make a marriage work after all.

title: a lot of fun
review: Wildly entertaining action-comedy about a bored married couple drifting apart due to the fact that they're both deadly assassins living secret lives and all the while unaware of each other's identities. Matters get even more complicated when they're both assigned to the same target, then forced by their competing agencies to hunt each other down. An ideal summer movie experience; from the moment it starts it's a pure adrenaline rush of energetic action scenes and hip dialogue, but the film's strongest asset is its clever since of humor. Pitt and Jolie are a sizzling duo, perform effective fight scenes/stunts, and spout diverting wisecracks that give the film a pleasant and playful feel throughout. It also manages to display some merits of a healthy marriage despite its silly, tongue-in-cheek content. An impressive showing from the director of The Bourne Identity, and sure to please fans just looking for a good time. ***

title: Shes Jewish hes company
review: Mr and Mrs Smith is a very entertaining movie. There were a lot of people laughing at the humorous parts of the movie when I saw it today. The directing by Doug Liman is OK. Both Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie are excellent actors. They play a husband and wife having marriage troubles who don't know that the other person is an assassin. Their sidekicks are interesting but this movie stops short of having an ensemble cast. The sets are really quite good. As respected film critic Roger Ebert said there is real chemistry between Pitt and Jolie in this film. Pitt works for the company which is slang for the CIA while Jolie is Jewish. America Canada and Britain helped Israel get statehood in 1948 because it was the right thing to do. Relations between the three countries have been cordial ever since. All three countries are united in trying to stop terrorism. The British Jewish and American characters in this film looked like they were on an intelligence exercise together. If CIA and MOSSAD agents ever married each other I think the world would go on and they could be genuinely in love too. I think that there should be a sequel or two to this movie.

title: Something for both sides of your brain
review:
"Mr. and Mrs. Smith" delivers two kinds of summer fare - the chic flick, and the action blockbuster - in one tasty package. The film opens with our stylishly-dressed couple at the marriage counselor. He says she's lost her spontaneity. She says he's too unreliable. When the counselor asks if they're honest with each other, she says, "Yes. Mostly."

Discovering exactly how honest, and how dishonest, they've been with each other is the driving question of the movie. But the answers to those questions come in the midst of flying bullets, pyrotechnics, chase scenes, close calls, and plenty of revealing shots for each actor.

Along the way, there is an intriguing subtext of the modern day roles of men and women in marriage, where passion comes from, and how succumbing to the first may spell the death of the second.

If you don't have an appreciation for both genres, you may find that either there's too much talking or alternately, there's too much violence. But if you enjoy both... or are thinking about a date with someone who strongly enjoys the other type of film... it's fun summer romp.

title: Would've been better if rated "R"...
review:
First of all, this is the second movie I've seen of Brad Pitt's (the first was IwtV) and about the third or fourth of Angelina's. The chemistry between the both of these fine actors was very much of an upgrade than that of Brad and Catherine Zeta-Jones in Ocean's Twelve. It had the right amount of comedy but a little bit of an overkill with the action.

The thing that bugged me the most about this movie was, of course, it was rated PG-13. I know that this year's movie supply hasn't been so great, but downgrading it to a PG-13 to attract even younger audiences won't help by much!

This movie could have been a little better by extending the scenes with Brad and Angelina, and also have more of a storyline. And by doing this, probably would have been rated "R" and been better for it. I saw better scenes in the commercials than I did in the movie itself!

Overall, the acting was well done, action was extensive but okay i suppose, and the comedy was on point. 3 and a half out of five stars.

title: Overall : good flick
review: This was a very good movie, although some parts had me wondering. There was also very good on-screen chemistry between Pitt and Jolie. I will admit though, this movie had an unexpected twist towards the end. The action was very cool, especially in the scenes where they meet up at the house to fight and the last shootout scene towards the end. I also thought that some of the scenes could have been cut out, like when they were trying to avoid one another, but it all worked out for the best in the end. I know one thing for sure, if there was ever a sequel to be made, I know that I would go and see it. I highly recommend this movie to action fans who also love a bit of comedy thrown into the story.

title: Good film - Not a remake of anything
review:
This film crackles with energy and excitement. Pitt and Jolie provide great chemistry, comic timing, and a clear mastery of weaponry. Their on screen presence is palpable. It is not a Hitchcock remake, It is not "Prizzi's Honor", nor is it "True Lies". It is different from the two aforementioned films in that it is unique in it's premise.

This is a dark love story/action film that is easy to follow. The dialog is smart, the action scenes well executed. The most captivating part of the film is that it is fun. The actors clearly enjoyed making the film, and the audience laughed heartily in response.

I have two points to criticize: 1. The sound editing - much of the exposition is done during car chases and explosions. It is difficult to hear some of the subtle dialog that lends itself to the story.

2. A few minor annoying plot holes, but not enough to detract in a major way.

This film is well worth the price of admission. Appropriate for ages 13 and up.

title: Best Action Comedy In Ten Years
review:
Usually your reviewer puts a lot of thought into the movie choice of the week, but this week he went with gut instinct (or perhaps lower), had low to middling expectations but was very pleasantly surprised with the result.

Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie star as John and Jane Smith, married for five, perhaps six years. John is a gut instinct kind of guy, who makes plans up on the spot, works out of a dockside warehouse (albeit with a Manhattan view), and is basically a bit of a slob. Jane, on the other hand, is a meticulous planner, is over-fussy about the way her household runs, and works in an all female office with décor similar to the X-Men headquarters.

We could go into the plot, but suffice to say the marriage has hit a calm spot - going to a marriage counselor with an upper middle class setting, reminded me somewhat of particular characters out of Desperate Housewives. Oh, and they still don't know each other is a top international assassin. Don't ask how they haven't found that out yet, it is not important to the enjoyment of the moment. As would probably happen with any further discussion of the plot.

Vince Vaughn does his usual quick talking sidekick role as well as ever (in this case, as Pitt's boss), and Adam Brody from TV's 'The OC' has more than a few lines as well. Apart from those two, the other characters all fit into one of two categories, either cannon fodder or cute girl in black. Yes, let's not think too deeply about character development either, put it in the same box as the plot shall we? The strengths of this movie are the action set pieces and the sly sense of humour throughout, sometimes combined in the same scene, such as the extended car chase, beginning and ending with 'Making Love, Out Of Nothing At All'.

Or, after doing a mark each early in the movie, heading to the Coleman's for a neighbourly 'thing' to the strains of Amy Grant's 'Baby Baby'  the look on Jolie's face when she holds a baby as if it is an alien is priceless. Continuing the music theme, stopping in the middle of a huge gun battle to take refuge in a lift, with 'The Girl From Ipanema' as background muzak, is another delicious moment.

There are just too many of these moments to put together a full list  do I include the dinner where they realize each other's secret life, every bite analyzed for ulterior motives? Or do I leave out Pitt's reaction to his toys taken away in a moment of Jolie spite (every man in the cinema sympathizing completely, I am sure). And on it goes, what to mention what to omit.

The comedy highpoint, however, has to be Brody wearing a Fight Club t-shirt. Took me straight back to Pitt discussing the rules in that earlier movie ('rule one, there is no fight club, rule two, there is no fight club'), and again, he plays the role of Mr Smith with a grin on his face and an ease everyone can see. Actually, everyone looks like they are enjoying themselves in this movie.

Come for the sex appeal, stay for the laughs and action. Not since Bad Boys has there been such a laugh out loud, fun, entertaining time at the movies  best action comedy of the decade thus far.

title: "True Lies" for couple
review:
"True Lies" for couples

Almost ten years ago, there was anonymous movie, named: True Lies, With AS and JLC, Mr and Mrs Smith enhanced the concept and bring us fun movie with great action motion This is a comedy and played well by Brad and Angelina. It seems that they like each other a lot on the set because they sure have fun on screen. I liked the fight club shirt  it was very funny. The movie use their jobs as special agents and reflect their secret life on the mediocre marriage couples. This is a great pre-SUMMER movie.

Go see it.

title: Violence
review: A tight and nicely pitched bit of boom bang-a-bang bang all the time with Brad Pitt and the impossibly eye catching Angelina Jolie as the couple drowning in the sort of domestic hell that Tyler Durden would have incinerated. What the couple don't know is that they're both assassins but someone else does find out and dispatches them to kill each other. That's it really. They find out, they fight, they exchange a few bitchy comments and destroy the matrimonial lair. Liman though is no slouch in the action department as he proved in the Bourne Identity and the couple bust each other up with enough destructive zeal to stop you getting bored, even if you're never exactly brimming with excitement. It's not much of comedy but there are a few mouth raising asides and Vince Vaughn is good value was Pitt's anxious friend and associate. A perfectly diverting two hours when all is said and done, sentiment free and worth seeing for Jolie's curves, the house is on fire moment and Seth from the O.C looking at an aggressive looking Pitt, wearing a fight club t-shirt, tied to a chair. Actually he didn't half look like Tyler did in the scene where Ed Norton was tied to that chair. Come to think of it, the Smith's shrine to unrestrained capitalism did go up in a firey ball of fury.

title: Surprisingly Funny Romantic Comedy
review:
In previous roles, neither Brad Pitt nor Angelina Jolie has shown that they have a flair for comedy. Because of this I was not expecting to laugh out loud while watching Mr. & Mrs. Smith, the much-gossiped about romantic comedy starring the two actors. But I did just that. Judging by the bursts of laughter from fellow moviegoers, I wasn't the only one who enjoyed this preposterously plotted flick.

The plot itself is somewhat absurd. A couple experience marital problems until they discover that they are both paid assassins who have been hired to kill one another. Putting aside the notion that the two actors are far too attractive to be paid assassins, it is difficult to believe that they could be married for five (make that six) years without knowing the other was a hired hit-man. Still, the movie is not meant for those questioning the quality of ideas coming out of Hollywood. This is a popcorn movie for those who want to escape the boredom of civilized suburbia.

What makes this movie work is the amazing chemistry Pitt and Jolie have on screen. There I said it. Sure I wanted to hate this movie for creating the tension that may have led, to the separation, of the world's most beautiful couple, but the truth is undeniable. Pitt and Jolie make a great couple - on film at least. The movie also benefits from some well-timed tongue-in-cheek screen writing and some fine comedic acting by Vince Vaughn. Vaughn plays John Smith's (Brad Pitt) faithful friend and sidekick and is mostly used as a comedic extra in the film.

The movie goes a little over board in the home-furnishing department, but I guess the producers were trying to appeal to the nation's indebted homeowners thinking of remodeling their abodes.

title: Mr. & Mrs. Mediocre
review: Okay, so this movie had Angelina & Brad - arguably the two most beautiful people in "Hollywood." The movie had its expected outcome: I won't mention it here, however, since some of us may not have seen it! There were moments of uncomfortable silence between the two in the movie, and some cheesy "honey" this and "honey" that to add to the feel of "we are married, despite the fact that we kill for a living behind each others' backs." I hope everyone who sees this movie will enjoy it as much as I have because it is charming and funny. Brad is gorgeous, Angelina HOT (and a bad ass) and the morale of the story is legendary! Sincerely, - Beau (see you soon!)

title: not THAT good,OK but complicated(favorite quotes 2)
review:
OK first of all i didn't get this movie 10% 1. why do they try 2 kill each other and they still love each other they even calls the other one ''sweat heart''.and the seen when ''john'' is kicking ''jane'' in her vagina and then she kicks him back in his d*ck,thats old comedy+does it even hurt when u kick a woman in he g-spot? P's tell me. 3 like why don't they kill each other when they have the chance? 4 why doesn't Angelina Jolie die when they are in the desert and then ''john'' shoots he with a big ass rocket launcher?

-christhesoccerguy@hotmail.com tell me your email please and don't forget 2 tell me your email!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

title: witty banter to the rescue
review: Regardless of how one feels about Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie's offscreen antics, its their on screen chemistry that really fires Mr. And Mrs. Smith. Without that chemistry much of the film would have been a disaster since the heart of the film is its spies lying to each other plot line. When Jolie and Pitt are on screen together sparks fly, whether they are having a nice dinner, sparing verbally or attempting to knock each other off. The film is full of funny lines that never seem to come off as one liners. They are merely funny things that you may think but never actually say to your spouse. And while the ending is one big noisy action set piece required of this sort of film the true excitement comes from the great dialogue and wonderful acting. Highly recommended for lovers of popcorn films.

title: Great hot movie!
review: This movie was a fun summer film. Jolie and Pitt are a dynamic duo, keeping you laughing, guessing, and ogling throughout the movie. Definitely worth the time and money. While the plot may seem very straightforward at firsts, it fails to be predictable, and remains exciting throughout the movie. While at the surface it appears to be simply an action movie, you will often burst out into laughter during the movie. There is also emotional back-story woven in through the movie, which was somewhat unexpected as well. However, the acting is really great, and the movie on a whole sits very solidly. I very much enjoyed it, because it kept you interested the whole time.

title: I dare you to watch 'Mr. and Mrs. Smith' and not have fun...
review:
Mr. and Mrs. Smith Jane and John Smith(Jolie and Pitt) don't seem to hit it off anymore. They met 5 or 6 years ago in Colombia, and from that point on, their relationship went uphill. Now, five or six years later, Jane and John have really become bored of their empty conversations between each other. Jane thinks John is a construction worker, and John thinks Jane works at a bank. But their worlds are going to be turned upside down...

Early in the film, we learn they are both assassins. We also learn they are both assassin hired to kill the same man. When both of them are at the scene, both are unsuccessful in their attempts to kill the victim, because they both suspect a riveling assassin at the scene. As they gather their own clues, they now know they are hired to kill each other...

The trailer for 'Mr. and Mrs. Smith' is misleading in a way. The film looks as if the entire running time is filled up with them trying to kill each other. But, this is not the whole story. After several unsuccessful attempts to kill each other, they both return to their house one night to battle it out.

One would think, at the climax of this scene, the film would end, telling us who wins. But, at the end of this battle, it leads to sex and laugh about the whole situation. Later, as a partnered team, they kidnap Benjamin(Brody) and discover that he was bait for them, and both of their sides wanted them to take each other out. From that point on, they are chased because they are worth 400,000 a piece.

I dare you to watch 'Mr. and Mrs Smith' and not have fun... 'Mr. and Mrs. Smith' is the funnest movie so far this year.

'Mr and Mrs. Smith' is filled with amazing chase scenes, witty humor and overflows with a genuine hipness and seductivity. This film works on almost every level it attempts to succeed on. The camera loves Jolie and Pitt, and you can tell they love the camera as well: Pitt's tough-guy yet sincere image, Jolie's butt-kicking, sassy girl character. The basic idea here is for us to see beautiful people blowing things up, and that's why one would buy a ticket here, particularly in the summer.

Although preposterous, 'Mr. and Mrs. Smith' is coated with such a silly, fun and hip texture, it's hard to resist.

'Mr. and Mrs. Smith': 4.5 from 5 PG13- intense sequences of action/violence and some sexual content/language.

title: no need for all the hype
review:
Finally saw the movie that has created much hype in the past few months. Was all the hype worth it? Not too sure

It seems as though the idea of this movie sprang forth in the following sequence: Take two known sexy actors, stick them in a dark, romantic comedy, add a few explosions and big guns here and there, don't forget the sexy sex scene and viola, a summer flick is born.

Creating incredible on screen chemistry together was no sweat for Jolie and Pitt. Their acting, however, deserved no standing ovation. The storyline of this flick is somewhat fresh, yet somewhat predictable. However, it is still a lot of fun to watch, especially with a spouse. After all, the movie certainly held a double meaning in many scenes that are related to marriage and the married life. It is no doubt an adult movie rather than a PG movie. But, I guess it is rated in accordance to where the money is!

The direction of the movie concentrated too much on the two characters as Jolie and Pitt, rather than Mr. and Mrs. Smith. Pay attention to all the unnecessary, extreme close-ups and the comedy that brought forth the personal lives of the two, rather than building on the characters. On the other hand, the message and the whole idea of "perfection and simplicity in marriage" which does not exist was very well done and enjoyable to watch.

To sum up, no need to make it a top priority, however, if the chance does arise, do take your husband/wife to Mr. & Mrs. Smith.

title: "You still alive, baby?"
review:
My husband and I just got back from seeing "Mr. and Mrs. Smith", which opened in theaters today. Normally I don't review current-run films, much less on the day they premiere, but I had planned beforehand to review this one. I knew I was going to enjoy it. Aside from and in spite of all the media speculation about Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt, I had a feeling it was going to be a fun film. I like Angelina Jolie and I especially like to watch her in action roles (yes I love and own the two Tomb Raider films). Seeing her run around with a big gun, kicking butt, is FUN. She's as great in this kind of role as Diana Rigg was as TV's Emma Peel! A perfect fit. And Brad Pitt is an underrated actor, he is really very good, and he is funny in this movie! He has great comedic timing.

The plot is simple. Two professional assassins find out that they've been hired to kill the other. The plot is only barely complicated by the facts that (1) they are married to each other, and (2) they did not know until this point of the story the other's true occupation.

The "eye candy" factor is high: Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie, often scantily dressed, heavily breathing lines such as "Who's your Daddy now?" It's also an action-packed movie, with good dialogue, great chemistry between Pitt and Jolie, and plenty of (not too bloody) violence. It's much more tongue-in-cheek than the trailers indicate. And Pitt and Jolie get some great one-liners.

All in all, a highly entertaining "popcorn" movie; great summer flick. As we walked to the car I said "It's sort of a mix of 'True Lies', 'Tomb Raider', 'The Avengers' (the old TV show, not that lousy movie), with a pinch of 'Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid' thrown in. I really enjoyed it." And look for a "Fight Club" reference, in the form of a t-shirt.

title: The perfect way to start the summer!!!
review:
This movie has been advertised and publicized and tabloid-ed for over 6 months, circulating rumors (and truths) have come out of the soup bowl and, in the end, Mr. and Mrs. Smith surpassed even MY expectations!

Brad and Angelina flow with ease as the uneasy, struggling, and dwindling married couple The Smith's, who are finding their marriage more of a struggle to live through then their jobs. When the truth is revealed to them both, the gloves and facades fall and the ammunition and knives come out.

The script is not as perfect as anyone would want it, but the actors and directing fuel this small engine to hit home hard. The action is very similar to Doug Liman's Bourne Identity, close up and in your face. It doesn't have the same touch as it does for Bourne, but it brings you into the action.

The summer has a perfect opening couple; Mr. and Mrs Smith is it's name.

title: Why cut the sex?
review: I don't know why they were trying to reach a younger audience by editing the would-be gritty sex scene to get the pg-13 rating. This movie is too smart for pubescent boys and girls on their first dates. Similar to Kill Bill in humor-action sense (minus the gore), and in character relationships. The behind the scenes look at spies was like an episode of The Venture Brothers. Bourne Identity + Arrested Development. Liman puts the "man" back in "LIMAN IS THE MAN" End comment. I don't like writing a minimum of ten lines. Ten lines is too many. Why should you have to read that much crap? I said all I wanted to say, just let me post!

title: Laughing With The Smiths
review:
Angelina Jolie is breathtaking while the ladies will certainly swoon over the ever-cool Brad Pitt. Even though the public probably views Jen as a better match for Mr. Smith, the arresting Jolie does a commendable job of playing his better half in the movie.

The action scenes are engaging but it's the playful and almost childlike exchange between the couple that keeps the audience entertained. While not known for his comedic talents, Pitt delivers the laughs in his own unique manner and the amusing Vince Vaughn only adds to the entertainment.

Although burdened with a predictable plot and an anticlimactic ending reminiscent of a 'Gun Kata' fight sequence from Kurt Wimmer's Equilibrium, one still enjoys the film for what it is, a fun movie.

title: I'd buy it on DVD, but I wouldn't pay retail.
review: I think this film was good value for money. It is entertaining and provides enough explosions and gunfire to entertain the average teenage male. Superior to, say, the James Bond formula, for two reasons: 1) Female lead character, who is not a damsel in distress, nor evil temptress 2) Less dialogue emphasis on gadgetry. Plus, the product-placement was less obvious, except the full-screen shot of Mr Smith's watch. There is definitely chemistry between the lead actors, and, surprisingly, the comedy was actually entertaining; though I think the director had problems maintaining tension in some of the action sequences.

title: Pretty funny
review: I had an okay expectation for this movie, and what I received was simply OK (well maybe a bit above okay at funny moments). There were hilarious parts in there that weren't part of the trailer (which is good because then you still get some fun). Also, the story itself actually wasn't so bad. It actually had a twist, but was a little predictable as the time came. I wish the movie had focused a little more on the story than just Pitt and Jolie's shots, although their shots are probably what enticed many to watch this movie. I'm definitely not an expert, but I think the shots were okay as well. My friends who went with me wanted to watch it again, and it's indeed very entertaining to watch again. Jolie seems a lot hotter than Pitt in the movie, maybe it's her dress. Oh yes and her cool gadgets were awesome. I thought there would be more gadgets in the film (I'm quite attracted to them), but not much more than the ones shown in the trailer. To sum up, this is an entertaining movie that won't let the average viewer down. It's pretty Hollywood though! Haha.

title: A sexier True lies...
review:
The only thing funny about this film is Vince Vaugn. Pitt and Jolie are good, but there's no great chemistry. There's hardly any supporting cast, other than Vaugn, so the whole film revolves around Pitt and Jolie, which becomes slightly boring and predictable (even if it is good eye candy for the audience). The dialogue is very suspect, but you can't knock the action sequences, especially the highway chase which is top dollar.

Of course it's sexy and glamorous, which is what you'd expect from a film with these two as the main characters, but it plays off that way too much, and the story fails due to there not being a genuine bad guy.

A decent Friday night date flick, but nothing more. Arnie and Jamie Lee Curtis still rule as the best undercover agents.
